14→我们将我们在当前所“拥有”的一切叫做*现象*。而在*现象*上，我们推断出一系列*现象*的运行方式/规律。我们似乎认为，所谓“现象的运行方式/规律”，既是前形而上学[^2]。
    15→
    16→前形而上学有一个**形式上的**错误理解，既是对“*上*”的理解。形而上学的英文，“*metaphysics*”，字面上来看，既是*元物理*。倘若把物理理解为*现象*，那么形而上学所描述的，既是产生现象的原因。然而事实上，请看上一段对形而上学的解释，形而上学事实上是**自现象而产生的**。所谓“上”，应当是我们**基于现象之上**而有的一套理解，而非自上而下由形而上**生成**了形。因此，*现象*，亦或者说我们所感受到的世界，对于我们而言，并非*生成的世界*，而是对于我们而言的“*第一实在*”[^25]。我们任何的对于现象的理解，都**基于**现象。唯有承认现象既是“*第一实在*”，我们才能够作出任何形而上的推断。
    17→
    18→请看如下例子：
    19→
    20→> 故失*道*而后*德*，失*德*而后*仁*，失*仁*而后*义*，失*义*而后*礼*。——老子
    21→
    22→其中，*道*，*德*，*仁*，*义*，*礼*，自前往后，既是从上至下。*道*生万物，*道*既是最“元始”的*元物理*（*metaphysics*），而有此往后，皆是*生成*的。因此，道既是最上者，是为形而上，而礼既是最下者，是为形。
    23→
    24→然而，礼事实上是从现象所总结出来的，我们不妨将这个**切实**的*现象*中的行为称之为“*现象礼*”，我对“*现象礼*”有一个**解释**，既是我对人时发乎于心的对他人感受，这个感受是我个人**切实**感受到的，因而是*现象*的一部分，因此我将其称之为“*现象仁*”。这个感受使得我想要去如何如何地对待他人，这种推动力（motivation）也是我所**切实**感受到的，因此我将其称之为“*现象义*”[^3]。“*现象礼*”不仅仅存在于在我对待他人时，也同样存在于其他人是如何对待他人上，我们便将“*现象仁*”和“*现象义*”作为我们对“*现象礼*”的**解释**推而广之。也就是说，因为“*现象礼*”（似乎）在我们周围的所有人身上都有体现，而我们认为（将“*现象礼*”解释为）“*现象仁*”产生了“*现象义*”又产生了”*现象礼*”，所以我们认为所有（行“现象礼”的）人都（应当）有这种“*现象仁*”[^4]。接下来，我们便把我们认为（应当是）人人皆而有之的东西，在这里便是“*现象仁*”，称之为“*德*”，而为什么会有这种人人皆而有之的**规律**呢？因为“*道*”[^24]。
    25→
    26→因此我们看到，在现象的层面上，*仁义*仅仅是对于*礼*的一个解释。对于我们看到的外在的*现象*而言，事实上我们仅仅看到了*现象*中的“*现象礼*”，因而我们**推断**出了“*现象义*”，续而由“*现象义*”**推断**出了“*现象仁*”，即便并**没有**任何**切实**的“*现象义*”和“*现象仁*”出现在我的*现象*中，因为**我**所感受到的发乎于心的感受和推动力仅仅是**我**在行“*现象礼*”时所感受到的，而我无法真正感受到**他人**的内心感受，仅仅是将我对“**自己**的‘*现象礼*’”的解释**套用**到了我们看到的**别人**所行的“*现象礼*”上。因此，别人身上的*仁义*，其实是由*现象*中的“*现象礼*”所生成的。但是我们在解释上却认为是由*仁*而生*义*，因*义*而行*礼*，“*现象礼*”反而是由*仁义*所生成的了。接下来，基于这种生成的*仁义*，我们便总结出来，“人都是有*仁*的”。但是，事实上是“人都是（**可以**）有*仁*的”，因为我们是从诸多有*仁*的人身上发现许多人都是有*仁*的，因此*仁*是我们归纳出来的一个**属性**（**property**）。但是我们最终对其的理解是“人都是（**应该**）有*仁*的”——或者说，“有*仁*的才是人”。因此人可以拥有的一个**属性**，在这里既是“*仁*”，反而变成了人的一个**定义**。而这些**定义**合起来，便定义了**什么是*人***——也就是“*德*”，使得*人*而成为*人*的东西。因此我们看到，事实上“*德*”也是由“*仁*”生成的，但是我们在理解上却认为，是因“*德*”而生“*仁*”：因为你是*人*，所以你要有*仁*。最后，“*德*”是一种一般的规律，因为凡事诸物皆有其*德*（我们认为他应该遵守的规律，使得一样东西成为其本身的东西），因而又将所有的“*德*”合起来，归纳抽象出“*道*”，因此“*道*”实则为“*德*”而生成的，我们却理解为“*道*”生成了“*德*”。
    27→
    28→因此，整个逻辑的顺序就被倒反过来。道生德，人德为仁，因仁生义，因义行礼。而这最后的“*礼*”已经不再是一开始的“*现象礼*”，因为从“*现象礼*”生成“*道*”的逻辑已经被**掩埋不见**，已经全部**失**去了，人们以为“*道*”才是最元始的*元物理*。因此最终生成的“*礼*”已然仅仅是一种规范，而不一定是最初的（解释上）发乎于心的而有的*现象礼*了。
    29→
    30→在实践中，这种失将继续层层下跌，逐末而忘本。上述并非对《老子》的解释，而是在这一段当中，恰好出现了这种自形而上至形的阶梯，因此将此作为一个例子。
    31→
    32→### 形而上
    33→

我们将我们在当前所“拥有”的一切叫做*现象*。而在*现象*上，我们推断出一系列*现象*的运行方式/规律。我们似乎认为，所谓“现象的运行方式/规律”，既是前形而上学[^2]。

前形而上学有一个**形式上的**错误理解，既是对“*上*”的理解。形而上学的英文，“*metaphysics*”，字面上来看，既是*元物理*。倘若把物理理解为*现象*，那么形而上学所描述的，既是产生现象的原因。然而事实上，请看上一段对形而上学的解释，形而上学事实上是**自现象而产生的**。所谓“上”，应当是我们**基于现象之上**而有的一套理解，而非自上而下由形而上**生成**了形。因此，*现象*，亦或者说我们所感受到的世界，对于我们而言，并非*生成的世界*，而是对于我们而言的“*第一实在*”[^25]。我们任何的对于现象的理解，都**基于**现象。唯有承认现象既是“*第一实在*”，我们才能够作出任何形而上的推断。

请看如下例子：

> 故失*道*而后*德*，失*德*而后*仁*，失*仁*而后*义*，失*义*而后*礼*。——老子

其中，*道*，*德*，*仁*，*义*，*礼*，自前往后，既是从上至下。*道*生万物，*道*既是最“元始”的*元物理*（*metaphysics*），而有此往后，皆是*生成*的。因此，道既是最上者，是为形而上，而礼既是最下者，是为形。

然而，礼事实上是从现象所总结出来的，我们不妨将这个**切实**的*现象*中的行为称之为“*现象礼*”，我对“*现象礼*”有一个**解释**，既是我对人时发乎于心的对他人感受，这个感受是我个人**切实**感受到的，因而是*现象*的一部分，因此我将其称之为“*现象仁*”。这个感受使得我想要去如何如何地对待他人，这种推动力（motivation）也是我所**切实**感受到的，因此我将其称之为“*现象义*”[^3]。“*现象礼*”不仅仅存在于在我对待他人时，也同样存在于其他人是如何对待他人上，我们便将“*现象仁*”和“*现象义*”作为我们对“*现象礼*”的**解释**推而广之。也就是说，因为“*现象礼*”（似乎）在我们周围的所有人身上都有体现，而我们认为（将“*现象礼*”解释为）“*现象仁*”产生了“*现象义*”又产生了”*现象礼*”，所以我们认为所有（行“现象礼”的）人都（应当）有这种“*现象仁*”[^4]。接下来，我们便把我们认为（应当是）人人皆而有之的东西，在这里便是“*现象仁*”，称之为“*德*”，而为什么会有这种人人皆而有之的**规律**呢？因为“*道*”[^24]。

因此我们看到，在现象的层面上，*仁义*仅仅是对于*礼*的一个解释。对于我们看到的外在的*现象*而言，事实上我们仅仅看到了*现象*中的“*现象礼*”，因而我们**推断**出了“*现象义*”，续而由“*现象义*”**推断**出了“*现象仁*”，即便并**没有**任何**切实**的“*现象义*”和“*现象仁*”出现在我的*现象*中，因为**我**所感受到的发乎于心的感受和推动力仅仅是**我**在行“*现象礼*”时所感受到的，而我无法真正感受到**他人**的内心感受，仅仅是将我对“**自己**的‘*现象礼*’”的解释**套用**到了我们看到的**别人**所行的“*现象礼*”上。因此，别人身上的*仁义*，其实是由*现象*中的“*现象礼*”所生成的。但是我们在解释上却认为是由*仁*而生*义*，因*义*而行*礼*，“*现象礼*”反而是由*仁义*所生成的了。接下来，基于这种生成的*仁义*，我们便总结出来，“人都是有*仁*的”。但是，事实上是“人都是（**可以**）有*仁*的”，因为我们是从诸多有*仁*的人身上发现许多人都是有*仁*的，因此*仁*是我们归纳出来的一个**属性**（**property**）。但是我们最终对其的理解是“人都是（**应该**）有*仁*的”——或者说，“有*仁*的才是人”。因此人可以拥有的一个**属性**，在这里既是“*仁*”，反而变成了人的一个**定义**。而这些**定义**合起来，便定义了**什么是*人***——也就是“*德*”，使得*人*而成为*人*的东西。因此我们看到，事实上“*德*”也是由“*仁*”生成的，但是我们在理解上却认为，是因“*德*”而生“*仁*”：因为你是*人*，所以你要有*仁*。最后，“*德*”是一种一般的规律，因为凡事诸物皆有其*德*（我们认为他应该遵守的规律，使得一样东西成为其本身的东西），因而又将所有的“*德*”合起来，归纳抽象出“*道*”，因此“*道*”实则为“*德*”而生成的，我们却理解为“*道*”生成了“*德*”。

因此，整个逻辑的顺序就被倒反过来。道生德，人德为仁，因仁生义，因义行礼。而这最后的“*礼*”已经不再是一开始的“*现象礼*”，因为从“*现象礼*”生成“*道*”的逻辑已经被**掩埋不见**，已经全部**失**去了，人们以为“*道*”才是最元始的*元物理*。因此最终生成的“*礼*”已然仅仅是一种规范，而不一定是最初的（解释上）发乎于心的而有的*现象礼*了。

在实践中，这种失将继续层层下跌，逐末而忘本。上述并非对《老子》的解释，而是在这一段当中，恰好出现了这种自形而上至形的阶梯，因此将此作为一个例子。

### 形而上

     3→section: 道德仁义礼 passage (lines 18-31 + footnotes 3, 4, 24)
     4→status: DRAFT
     5→date: 2026-02-10
     6→conventions applied:
     7→  - 文言 block quote format (unanimous)
     8→  - Laozi block quote in full English with semantic weight
     9→  - 德 split: "virtue" in block quote → "(constitutive) character" in analysis
    10→  - 仁/义/礼 consistent throughout (humaneness, rightness, ritual conduct)
    11→  - 现象X = "phenomenal X" always
    12→  - Attribution TN for Laozi quote
    13→  - 德 shift TN at transition
    14→  - Author's footnotes translated
    15→---
    16→
    17→# Essay4-DaoDeRenYiLi
    18→
    19→## Original Chinese
    20→
    21→> 请看如下例子：
    22→>
    23→> > 故失*道*而后*德*，失*德*而后*仁*，失*仁*而后*义*，失*义*而后*礼*。——老子
    24→
    25→---
    26→
    27→## Draft Translation
    28→
    29→Consider the following example:
    30→
    31→> 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。
    32→> —— Laozi, *Daodejing* Ch. 38
    33→
    34→"When the Way (道, *dao*) was lost, there was virtue (德, *de*); when virtue was lost, there was humaneness (仁, *ren*); when humaneness was lost, there was rightness (义, *yi*); when rightness was lost, there was ritual conduct (礼, *li*)."[^TN1]
    35→
    36→Here, the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, and ritual conduct run from first to last as from top to bottom. The Way generates all things; the Way is the most "primordial" *metaphysics*, and everything that follows from it is *generated*. Thus the Way is the highest — it is the metaphysical — while ritual conduct is the lowest — it is the phenomenal.[^TN2]
    37→
    38→However, ritual conduct is in fact summarized from phenomena. Let us call the **actual** behavior in phenomena "phenomenal ritual conduct." I have an **explanation** for phenomenal ritual conduct: it is the feeling that arises from within me when I face another person — a feeling of concern for the other. This feeling is something I **actually** feel, and is therefore part of phenomena; I call it "phenomenal humaneness." This feeling impels me to treat the other person in such-and-such a way; this driving force (*motivation*) is also something I **actually** feel, and so I call it "phenomenal rightness."[^3] Phenomenal ritual conduct exists not only in how I treat others, but also in how other people treat one another. We therefore extend phenomenal humaneness and phenomenal rightness as our **explanation** of phenomenal ritual conduct more broadly. That is to say: because phenomenal ritual conduct (apparently) manifests in everyone around us, and because we interpret phenomenal ritual conduct as "phenomenal humaneness generates phenomenal rightness, which in turn generates phenomenal ritual conduct," we conclude that everyone who practices phenomenal ritual conduct (ought to) possess this phenomenal humaneness.[^4]
    39→
    40→Next, we take what we believe (ought to be) universally possessed — here, phenomenal humaneness — and call it "character."[^TN3] And why should there be such a universal pattern? Because of "the Way."[^24]
    41→
    42→We can now see that, at the level of phenomena, humaneness and rightness are merely an *explanation* of ritual conduct. As for what we observe of external phenomena, in fact we have only seen the phenomenal ritual conduct within phenomena, and from it we **infer** phenomenal rightness, and from phenomenal rightness we **infer** phenomenal humaneness — even though **no** actual phenomenal rightness or phenomenal humaneness appears in *my* phenomena, because the feeling that arises from within and the driving force are only what **I** feel when **I** practice phenomenal ritual conduct. I cannot truly feel **another person's** inner feelings; I have merely **applied** my explanation of "**my own** phenomenal ritual conduct" to the phenomenal ritual conduct we observe **others** performing. Therefore, the humaneness and rightness in other people are in fact *generated from* the phenomenal ritual conduct in phenomena. But in our interpretation, we take it to be the reverse: humaneness generates rightness, and rightness issues in ritual conduct — as though phenomenal ritual conduct were generated *by* humaneness and rightness.
    43→
    44→Next, on the basis of this generated humaneness and rightness, we conclude: "all people possess humaneness." But in fact it is: "all people (**can**) possess humaneness," since we discovered from many people who exhibit humaneness that many people have it — humaneness is thus a **property** we have inductively generalized. Yet our final understanding becomes: "all people (**should**) possess humaneness" — or rather, "only those who possess humaneness count as human." And so a **property** that a person can have — here, humaneness — is transformed into a **definition** of personhood. These definitions, taken together, define **what a person is** — that is, "character": that which makes a person a person.[^TN4] We thus see that character, too, is in fact generated from humaneness — yet in our understanding we take it to be the reverse: *because* you are a person, *therefore* you must possess humaneness. Finally, character is a general pattern, because all things have their character (the pattern we take them to follow, that which makes a thing what it is), and so we gather all instances of character together, inductively abstract from them, and arrive at "the Way." The Way, then, is in fact generated from character — yet we understand it as the Way generating character.
    45→
    46→Thus the entire logical order is reversed. The Way generates character; the character of a person is humaneness; from humaneness arises rightness; from rightness comes ritual conduct. But this final "ritual conduct" is no longer the original phenomenal ritual conduct, because the logic by which phenomenal ritual conduct generated "the Way" has been **buried from view** — it has been entirely **lost**. People take the Way to be the most primordial metaphysics. And so the ritual conduct that is finally generated is now merely a norm, and not necessarily the original phenomenal ritual conduct that (in the explanation) arose from within the heart.
    47→
    48→In practice, this loss continues cascading downward, level after level — pursuing the branches and forgetting the root. The above is not an interpretation of the *Laozi*; rather, in this passage there happens to appear precisely this kind of staircase running from the metaphysical down to the phenomenal, and so I use it here as an example.
    49→
    50→---
    51→
    52→## Footnotes
    53→
    54→[^3]: Humaneness, rightness, and ritual conduct are in fact already a metaphysical framework. And yet we cannot help but rely on some framework to describe phenomena; thus even though I have tried my utmost to restore their original phenomenal character, the account remains imprecise. In Chinese philosophy, humaneness and rightness are often mentioned together. Humaneness (仁) is said to be *loving others*; rightness (义) is said to be *what one ought to do*. In the conventional understanding — to take loving one's father as an example of humaneness — what I *ought to do* out of love for my father is rightness. And the concrete behavior that fulfills this rightness is ritual conduct. Rightness is thus the thing that connects humaneness to concrete action (ritual conduct). At the phenomenal level, I use "phenomenal humaneness" to describe the inner feeling (of love) I have toward my father — a feeling that impels me to act in certain ways. This driving force, this "motivation" itself, is what connects my feeling (phenomenal humaneness) to my behavior (phenomenal ritual conduct), and so it is fitting to call it phenomenal rightness.
    55→
    56→[^4]: The phenomenal humaneness and phenomenal rightness thus extended to others are no longer within *my* phenomena.
    57→
    58→[^24]: A note of caution: the interpretation of "the Way" (道) more faithful to Daoist thought would be closer to *that which makes existence itself possible* — pictorially, something like the canvas on which a painting is made. Here, we are merely expressing in structural terms that "the Way" can be understood to determine and generate "character."
    59→
    60→---
    61→
    62→## Translator's Notes
    63→
    64→[^TN1]: Translation adapted from Ivanhoe (2003). Key terms follow this volume's glossary. Cf. Ivanhoe: "When the Way was lost there was Virtue; When Virtue was lost there was benevolence; When benevolence was lost there was righteousness; When righteousness was lost there were the rites." We render 仁 as "humaneness" (following Ames & Rosemont) rather than "benevolence," 义 as "rightness" rather than "righteousness" to capture the author's usage as motivational disposition rather than moral judgment, and 礼 as "ritual conduct" to emphasize the behavioral dimension.
    65→
    66→[^TN2]: The author interprets 形 (xing, "form") in the classical term 形而上 as equivalent to 现象 (phenomena). In the *Xici zhuan* (Commentary on the Appended Phrases, *Yijing*), 形 conventionally means "visible form" or "physical shape." The author's reinterpretation — phenomena as the ground, the metaphysical as what is built upon it — is a significant philosophical departure. See the Translator's Introduction for further discussion.
    67→
    68→[^TN3]: The author now reconceives 德 (de) not as virtue in the moral sense but as (constitutive) character — the defining characteristics that make a thing what it is, assembled bottom-up from phenomena rather than imposed top-down from metaphysical principle. Hereafter shortened to "character." This constructivist reading departs from both the standard Confucian sense of 德 as moral virtue and the Daoist sense of 德 as natural potency.
    69→
    70→[^TN4]: Note the crucial reversal: a *property* that people happen to have (observed inductively) becomes a *definition* of what people are (imposed normatively). This is the mechanism by which phenomena are transformed into the metaphysical — the bottom-up construction is concealed, and the result appears to be top-down.

# Essay4-DaoDeRenYiLi

## Original Chinese

> 请看如下例子：
>
> > 故失*道*而后*德*，失*德*而后*仁*，失*仁*而后*义*，失*义*而后*礼*。——老子

---

## Draft Translation

Consider the following example:

> 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼。
> —— Laozi, *Daodejing* Ch. 38

"When the Way (道, *dao*) was lost, there was virtue (德, *de*); when virtue was lost, there was humaneness (仁, *ren*); when humaneness was lost, there was rightness (义, *yi*); when rightness was lost, there was ritual conduct (礼, *li*)."[^TN1]

Here, the Way, virtue, humaneness, rightness, and ritual conduct run from first to last as from top to bottom. The Way generates all things; the Way is the most "primordial" *metaphysics*, and everything that follows from it is *generated*. Thus the Way is the highest — it is the metaphysical — while ritual conduct is the lowest — it is the phenomenal.[^TN2]

However, ritual conduct is in fact summarized from phenomena. Let us call the **actual** behavior in phenomena "phenomenal ritual conduct." I have an **explanation** for phenomenal ritual conduct: it is the feeling that arises from within me when I face another person — a feeling of concern for the other. This feeling is something I **actually** feel, and is therefore part of phenomena; I call it "phenomenal humaneness." This feeling impels me to treat the other person in such-and-such a way; this driving force (*motivation*) is also something I **actually** feel, and so I call it "phenomenal rightness."[^3] Phenomenal ritual conduct exists not only in how I treat others, but also in how other people treat one another. We therefore extend phenomenal humaneness and phenomenal rightness as our **explanation** of phenomenal ritual conduct more broadly. That is to say: because phenomenal ritual conduct (apparently) manifests in everyone around us, and because we interpret phenomenal ritual conduct as "phenomenal humaneness generates phenomenal rightness, which in turn generates phenomenal ritual conduct," we conclude that everyone who practices phenomenal ritual conduct (ought to) possess this phenomenal humaneness.[^4]

Next, we take what we believe (ought to be) universally possessed — here, phenomenal humaneness — and call it "character."[^TN3] And why should there be such a universal pattern? Because of "the Way."[^24]

We can now see that, at the level of phenomena, humaneness and rightness are merely an *explanation* of ritual conduct. As for what we observe of external phenomena, in fact we have only seen the phenomenal ritual conduct within phenomena, and from it we **infer** phenomenal rightness, and from phenomenal rightness we **infer** phenomenal humaneness — even though **no** actual phenomenal rightness or phenomenal humaneness appears in *my* phenomena, because the feeling that arises from within and the driving force are only what **I** feel when **I** practice phenomenal ritual conduct. I cannot truly feel **another person's** inner feelings; I have merely **applied** my explanation of "**my own** phenomenal ritual conduct" to the phenomenal ritual conduct we observe **others** performing. Therefore, the humaneness and rightness in other people are in fact *generated from* the phenomenal ritual conduct in phenomena. But in our interpretation, we take it to be the reverse: humaneness generates rightness, and rightness issues in ritual conduct — as though phenomenal ritual conduct were generated *by* humaneness and rightness.

Next, on the basis of this generated humaneness and rightness, we conclude: "all people possess humaneness." But in fact it is: "all people (**can**) possess humaneness," since we discovered from many people who exhibit humaneness that many people have it — humaneness is thus a **property** we have inductively generalized. Yet our final understanding becomes: "all people (**should**) possess humaneness" — or rather, "only those who possess humaneness count as human." And so a **property** that a person can have — here, humaneness — is transformed into a **definition** of personhood. These definitions, taken together, define **what a person is** — that is, "character": that which makes a person a person.[^TN4] We thus see that character, too, is in fact generated from humaneness — yet in our understanding we take it to be the reverse: *because* you are a person, *therefore* you must possess humaneness. Finally, character is a general pattern, because all things have their character (the pattern we take them to follow, that which makes a thing what it is), and so we gather all instances of character together, inductively abstract from them, and arrive at "the Way." The Way, then, is in fact generated from character — yet we understand it as the Way generating character.

Thus the entire logical order is reversed. The Way generates character; the character of a person is humaneness; from humaneness arises rightness; from rightness comes ritual conduct. But this final "ritual conduct" is no longer the original phenomenal ritual conduct, because the logic by which phenomenal ritual conduct generated "the Way" has been **buried from view** — it has been entirely **lost**. People take the Way to be the most primordial metaphysics. And so the ritual conduct that is finally generated is now merely a norm, and not necessarily the original phenomenal ritual conduct that (in the explanation) arose from within the heart.

In practice, this loss continues cascading downward, level after level — pursuing the branches and forgetting the root. The above is not an interpretation of the *Laozi*; rather, in this passage there happens to appear precisely this kind of staircase running from the metaphysical down to the phenomenal, and so I use it here as an example.

---

## Footnotes

[^3]: Humaneness, rightness, and ritual conduct are in fact already a metaphysical framework. And yet we cannot help but rely on some framework to describe phenomena; thus even though I have tried my utmost to restore their original phenomenal character, the account remains imprecise. In Chinese philosophy, humaneness and rightness are often mentioned together. Humaneness (仁) is said to be *loving others*; rightness (义) is said to be *what one ought to do*. In the conventional understanding — to take loving one's father as an example of humaneness — what I *ought to do* out of love for my father is rightness. And the concrete behavior that fulfills this rightness is ritual conduct. Rightness is thus the thing that connects humaneness to concrete action (ritual conduct). At the phenomenal level, I use "phenomenal humaneness" to describe the inner feeling (of love) I have toward my father — a feeling that impels me to act in certain ways. This driving force, this "motivation" itself, is what connects my feeling (phenomenal humaneness) to my behavior (phenomenal ritual conduct), and so it is fitting to call it phenomenal rightness.

[^4]: The phenomenal humaneness and phenomenal rightness thus extended to others are no longer within *my* phenomena.

[^24]: A note of caution: the interpretation of "the Way" (道) more faithful to Daoist thought would be closer to *that which makes existence itself possible* — pictorially, something like the canvas on which a painting is made. Here, we are merely expressing in structural terms that "the Way" can be understood to determine and generate "character."

---

## Translator's Notes

[^TN1]: Translation adapted from Ivanhoe (2003). Key terms follow this volume's glossary. Cf. Ivanhoe: "When the Way was lost there was Virtue; When Virtue was lost there was benevolence; When benevolence was lost there was righteousness; When righteousness was lost there were the rites." We render 仁 as "humaneness" (following Ames & Rosemont) rather than "benevolence," 义 as "rightness" rather than "righteousness" to capture the author's usage as motivational disposition rather than moral judgment, and 礼 as "ritual conduct" to emphasize the behavioral dimension.

[^TN2]: The author interprets 形 (xing, "form") in the classical term 形而上 as equivalent to 现象 (phenomena). In the *Xici zhuan* (Commentary on the Appended Phrases, *Yijing*), 形 conventionally means "visible form" or "physical shape." The author's reinterpretation — phenomena as the ground, the metaphysical as what is built upon it — is a significant philosophical departure. See the Translator's Introduction for further discussion.

[^TN3]: The author now reconceives 德 (de) not as virtue in the moral sense but as (constitutive) character — the defining characteristics that make a thing what it is, assembled bottom-up from phenomena rather than imposed top-down from metaphysical principle. Hereafter shortened to "character." This constructivist reading departs from both the standard Confucian sense of 德 as moral virtue and the Daoist sense of 德 as natural potency.

[^TN4]: Note the crucial reversal: a *property* that people happen to have (observed inductively) becomes a *definition* of what people are (imposed normatively). This is the mechanism by which phenomena are transformed into the metaphysical — the bottom-up construction is concealed, and the result appears to be top-down.

## Buddhism Expert Review: Essay 4 道德仁义礼 Passage Draft

### Overall assessment

This is a strong draft. The translation is accurate, readable, and faithful to the author's argument. The TNs are well-placed and informative. The 文言 block quote format is correctly applied. I have no major objections — my comments are refinements, not corrections.

---

### What works well

1. **The reversal structure is clear.** The reader can follow the bottom-up construction (phenomenal ritual conduct → phenomenal humaneness → character → the Way) and then see the inversion (the Way → character → humaneness → ritual conduct). This is the passage's philosophical payload, and it lands.

2. **The 德 split works.** "Virtue" in the block quote → "character" in the analysis (via TN3) is smooth. The reader feels the shift without confusion.

3. **"Phenomenal X" compounds are consistent.** Never dropped, always present. Good.

4. **Footnote 3 translation is excellent.** The father-love example is clearly rendered. The explanation of 义 as the connector between feeling and action is precise.

5. **Footnote 24 translation is accurate.** The canvas/painting metaphor works.

---

### Comments from Buddhism/Madhyamaka perspective

**1. The property→definition reversal (lines 44, TN4) — this is structurally parallel to Nagarjuna's critique of svabhava, and the translation captures it well without needing to say so.**

The move from "people CAN have humaneness" → "people SHOULD have humaneness" → "only those with humaneness ARE people" maps precisely onto what Nagarjuna critiques: taking an observed regularity (a property) and reifying it into an intrinsic nature (svabhava). The author is doing Madhyamaka-style deconstruction without Buddhist terminology. TN4 correctly flags the reversal mechanism. I would NOT add a Buddhist cross-reference here — it would import a framework the author is not invoking. Just noting that the translation faithfully preserves this structure.

**2. The word "generated" (生成) — consider whether it is carrying the right weight.**

The draft uses "generated" throughout for 生成. This is accurate. But from a Buddhist perspective, the key philosophical distinction is between two senses of "generation" in the passage:

- (a) The actual phenomenal process: phenomenal ritual conduct → inference → phenomenal humaneness (this is *epistemic* generation — we construct an interpretation)
- (b) The inverted metaphysical picture: the Way → character → humaneness → ritual conduct (this is *ontological* generation — one thing brings another into being)

The author's argument is that (a) gets concealed and replaced by (b). The English "generated" works for both, which is good — it preserves the ambiguity that allows the inversion to feel seamless. But you might consider whether the first few uses of "generated" (in the metaphysical picture, line 36: "the Way generates all things") should be slightly marked — perhaps italicized — to signal that this is the conventional/illusory reading that will be deconstructed. This parallels the Buddhist pedagogical strategy of first presenting the conventional view (samvriti) and then showing its constructed character (paramartha). The author's own Chinese uses italics for 生成 in some places.

**3. "Buried from view" (掩埋不见) — excellent rendering.**

This captures what the Buddhists call avidya (ignorance) in a non-Buddhist register: the constructive process is not denied but *concealed*. The concealment is what makes the inversion seem natural. "Buried from view" preserves both the active concealment and the fact that the original structure still exists underneath — it is buried, not destroyed. This is precisely right.

**4. "Pursuing the branches and forgetting the root" (逐末而忘本) — good, but consider a brief gloss.**

This is a classical Chinese idiom. An English reader will get the metaphorical sense, but might not realize it is an established idiom rather than the author's own coinage. A very brief parenthetical or TN noting this is a classical expression could help — but this is a minor point and could also be left as is. The meaning comes through.

**5. Footnote 24 — one small accuracy concern.**

The original: "更加符合道家的关于'道'的解释更类似于使得存在得以成立的那个东西"

Draft: "the interpretation of 'the Way' (道) more faithful to Daoist thought would be closer to *that which makes existence itself possible*"

This is good, but "makes existence itself possible" adds a modal dimension ("possible") that the Chinese doesn't quite have. The original says "使得存在得以成立" — "that which makes existence stand/hold" or "that which enables existence to be established." The difference is subtle: "makes possible" suggests a condition of possibility (Kantian overtone), while "makes established/stand" suggests a sustaining ground (more Daoist). Consider: "that which enables existence to stand" or "that which makes existence hold." This keeps the Daoist resonance — 道 as the sustaining ground, the canvas on which the painting exists — without importing Kantian "conditions of possibility."

**6. The block quote Laozi translation — "there was virtue" vs "virtue appeared."**

Minor point. The draft follows Ivanhoe/Lau with "there was virtue." The Chinese 故失道而后德 literally says "when [X] was lost, afterward [Y]." Some translators render this as "[Y] appeared" (suggesting emergence), others as "there was [Y]" (suggesting presence). Both work. "There was" is slightly more neutral and I think it's the right choice here, since the author's subsequent analysis will explain the mechanism of emergence in detail. No change needed.

---

### One thing to watch

The passage is long and dense. The English paragraphs (especially lines 42-44) are very long — single paragraphs containing multiple philosophical moves. The Chinese is equally dense (the original line 26 is one enormous paragraph), so this is faithful. But consider whether the English reader needs a paragraph break where the Chinese doesn't have one — specifically at the "接下来" (Next) transition in line 26. The draft does break at "Next, on the basis of this generated humaneness..." (line 44), which is good. Just flagging that paragraph length management matters here.

---

### Summary

Strong draft. My only substantive suggestion is the footnote 24 wording ("enables existence to stand" instead of "makes existence possible"). Everything else is either praise or minor refinements that could go either way. The passage's structural parallel to Madhyamaka deconstruction of svabhava is faithfully preserved without being explicitly invoked — which is exactly right for this author.
